And what we've found is um it's complicated if you try to do these reactions in aqueous it's not impossible it's very you know challenging to um to to do the analysis actually because you have many branching um pathways depending on how you prepare your electrolytes but we've been looking in non-aqueous systems so far and uh and see the feasibility that you can electrochemically cleave the nitrogen carbon bond directly and um take CO2 to something else if you can make it if you give it a very strong thermodynamic sink like to make a carbonate an alkali carbonate it works fairly well and you can um go directly you know CO2 all the way to a carbonate in a reactor but then the question is you've got the price of making the co-reactant so we don't get like a calcium ions or magnesium ions for free and so thinking about how you actually when you expand the box and uh where where do you source whatever you're mineralizing CO2 with uh that's always a challenge so if you can source that from somewhere like ocean water you know maybe there's some kind of hybrid concept there but but that's the challenge uh how do you make it really um you know net removal of CO2 because you have to create the reactive ions.
